defs.docs: Cross-platform file system notification library

attributes.value: / Cross-platform file system notification library
/ # Installation
/ ```toml
/ [dependencies]
/ notify = "5.0.0-pre.10"
/ ## Serde
/ Events are serialisable via [serde] if the `serde` feature is enabled:
/ ```toml
/ notify = { version = "5.0.0-pre.10", features = ["serde"] }
/ [serde]: https://serde.rs
/ # Examples
/ use notify::{Watcher, RecommendedWatcher, RecursiveMode, Result};
/ fn main() -> Result<()> {
/     // Automatically select the best implementation for your platform.
/     let mut watcher: RecommendedWatcher = Watcher::new_immediate(|res| {
/         match res {
/            Ok(event) => println!("event: {:?}", event),
/            Err(e) => println!("watch error: {:?}", e),
/     // Add a path to be watched. All files and directories at that path and
/     // below will be monitored for changes.
/     watcher.watch(".", RecursiveMode::Recursive)?;
/ ## With precise events
/ By default, Notify emits non-descript events containing only the affected path and some
/ metadata. To get richer details about _what_ the events are about, you need to enable
/ [`Config::PreciseEvents`](config/enum.Config.html#variant.PreciseEvents). The full event
/ classification is described in the [`event`](event/index.html) module documentation.
/ # use notify::{Watcher, RecommendedWatcher, RecursiveMode, Result};
/ # use std::time::Duration;
/ # fn main() -> Result<()> {
/ # // Automatically select the best implementation for your platform.
/ # let mut watcher: RecommendedWatcher = Watcher::new_immediate(|res| {
/ #     match res {
/ #        Ok(event) => println!("event: {:?}", event),
/ #        Err(e) => println!("watch error: {:?}", e),
/ # // Add a path to be watched. All files and directories at that path and
/ # // below will be monitored for changes.
/ # watcher.watch(".", RecursiveMode::Recursive)?;
/ use notify::Config;
/ watcher.configure(Config::PreciseEvents(true))?;
/ ## With different configurations
/ It is possible to create several watchers with different configurations or implementations that
/ all call the same event function. This can accommodate advanced behaviour or work around limits.
/ # use notify::{RecommendedWatcher, RecursiveMode, Result, Watcher};
/ # fn main() -> Result<()> {
/       fn event_fn(res: Result<notify::Event>) {
/           match res {
/              Ok(event) => println!("event: {:?}", event),
/              Err(e) => println!("watch error: {:?}", e),
/       let mut watcher1: RecommendedWatcher = Watcher::new_immediate(event_fn)?;
/       let mut watcher2: RecommendedWatcher = Watcher::new_immediate(event_fn)?;
/ #     watcher1.watch(".", RecursiveMode::Recursive)?;
/ #     watcher2.watch(".", RecursiveMode::Recursive)?;
deny(missing_docs)

/ [ref]: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa363950(v=vs.85).aspx

defs.name: RemoveKind
defs.value: pub enum RemoveKind { Any, File, Folder, Other, }
defs.docs: An event describing removal operations on files.

attributes.value: / An event describing removal operations on files.

defs.name: Any
defs.docs: The catch-all event kind, for unsupported/unknown events.

attributes.value: / The catch-all event kind, for unsupported/unknown events.
/ This variant should be used as the "else" case when mapping native kernel bitmasks or
/ bitmaps, such that if the mask is ever extended with new event types the backend will not
/ gain bugs due to not matching new unknown event types.
/ This variant is also the default variant used when Notify is in "imprecise" mode.

defs.name: Access
defs.docs: An event describing non-mutating access operations on files.

attributes.value: / An event describing non-mutating access operations on files.
/ This event is about opening and closing file handles, as well as executing files, and any
/ other such event that is about accessing files, folders, or other structures rather than
/ mutating them.
/ Only some platforms are capable of generating these.

defs.name: Create
defs.docs: An event describing creation operations on files.

attributes.value: / An event describing creation operations on files.
/ This event is about the creation of files, folders, or other structures but not about e.g.
/ writing new content into them.

defs.name: Modify
defs.docs: An event describing mutation of content, name, or metadata.

attributes.value: / An event describing mutation of content, name, or metadata.
/ This event is about the mutation of files', folders', or other structures' content, name
/ (path), or associated metadata (attributes).

defs.name: Remove
defs.docs: An event describing removal operations on files.

attributes.value: / An event describing removal operations on files.
/ This event is about the removal of files, folders, or other structures but not e.g. erasing
/ content from them. This may also be triggered for renames/moves that move files _out of the
/ watched subpath_.
/ Some editors also trigger Remove events when saving files as they may opt for removing (or
/ renaming) the original then creating a new file in-place.

defs.name: Other
defs.docs: An event not fitting in any of the above four categories.

attributes.value: / An event not fitting in any of the above four categories.
/ This may be used for meta-events about the watch itself. In "imprecise" mode, it is, along
/ with `Any`, the only other event generated.

defs.name: EventKind
defs.value:
pub enum EventKind {
    Any,
    Access(AccessKind),
    Create(CreateKind),
    Modify(ModifyKind),
    Remove(RemoveKind),
    Other,
}
defs.docs: Top-level event kind.

attributes.value: / Top-level event kind.
/ This is arguably the most important classification for events. All subkinds below this one
/ represent details that may or may not be available for any particular backend, but most tools
/ and Notify systems will only care about which of these four general kinds an event is about.

defs.name: is_access
defs.docs: Indicates whether an event is an Access variant.

attributes.value: / Indicates whether an event is an Access variant.

defs.name: is_create
defs.docs: Indicates whether an event is a Create variant.

attributes.value: / Indicates whether an event is a Create variant.

defs.name: is_modify
defs.docs: Indicates whether an event is a Modify variant.

attributes.value: / Indicates whether an event is a Modify variant.

defs.name: is_remove
defs.docs: Indicates whether an event is a Remove variant.

attributes.value: / Indicates whether an event is a Remove variant.

defs.name: is_other
defs.docs: Indicates whether an event is an Other variant.

attributes.value: / Indicates whether an event is an Other variant.

defs.name: Event
defs.docs: Notify event.

attributes.value: / Notify event.

defs.name: kind
defs.docs: Kind or type of the event.

attributes.value: / Kind or type of the event.
/ This is a hierarchy of enums describing the event as precisely as possible. All enums in
/ the hierarchy have two variants always present, `Any` and `Other`, accompanied by one or
/ more specific variants.
/ `Any` should be used when more detail about the event is not known beyond the variant
/ already selected. For example, `AccessMode::Any` means a file has been accessed, but that's
/ all we know.
/ `Other` should be used when more detail _is_ available, but cannot be encoded as one of the
/ defined variants. When specifying `Other`, the event attributes should contain an `Info`
/ entry with a short string identifying this detail. That string is to be considered part of
/ the interface of the backend (i.e. a change should probably be breaking).
/ For example, `CreateKind::Other` with an `Info("mount")` may indicate the binding of a
/ mount. The documentation of the particular backend should indicate if any `Other` events
/ are generated, and what their description means.
/ The `EventKind::Any` variant should be used as the "else" case when mapping native kernel
/ bitmasks or bitmaps, such that if the mask is ever extended with new event types the
/ backend will not gain bugs due to not matching new unknown event types.

defs.name: paths
defs.docs: Paths the event is about, if known.

attributes.value: / Paths the event is about, if known.
/ If an event concerns two or more paths, and the paths are known at the time of event
/ creation, they should all go in this `Vec`. Otherwise, using the `Tracker` attr may be more
/ appropriate.
/ The order of the paths is likely to be significant! For example, renames where both ends of
/ the name change are known will have the "source" path first, and the "target" path last.

defs.name: attrs
defs.docs: Additional attributes of the event.

attributes.value: / Additional attributes of the event.
/ Arbitrary data may be added to this field, without restriction beyond the `Sync` and
/ `Clone` properties. Some data added here is considered for comparing and hashing, but not
/ all: at this writing this is `Tracker`, `Flag`, `Info`, and `Source`.

defs.name: EventAttributes
defs.docs: Additional attributes of the event.

attributes.value: / Additional attributes of the event.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Creates a new `EventAttributes`.

attributes.value: / Creates a new `EventAttributes`.

defs.docs: Retrieves the tracker ID for an event directly, if present.

attributes.value: / Retrieves the tracker ID for an event directly, if present.

attributes.value: / Retrieves the Notify flag for an event directly, if present.

attributes.value: / Retrieves the additional info for an event directly, if present.

defs.name: source

attributes.value: / Retrieves the source for an event directly, if present.

attributes.value: / The process ID of the originator of the event.
/ This attribute is experimental and, while included in Notify itself, is not considered
/ stable or standard enough to be part of the serde, eq, hash, and debug representations.

defs.docs: Sets the Notify flag onto the event.

defs.name: Rescan
defs.docs:
Rescan notices are emitted by some platforms (and may also be emitted by Notify itself).
 They indicate either a lapse in the events or a change in the filesystem such that events
 received so far can no longer be relied on to represent the state of the filesystem now.

attributes.value: / Rescan notices are emitted by some platforms (and may also be emitted by Notify itself).
/ They indicate either a lapse in the events or a change in the filesystem such that events
/ received so far can no longer be relied on to represent the state of the filesystem now.
/ An application that simply reacts to file changes may not care about this. An application
/ that keeps an in-memory representation of the filesystem will need to care, and will need
/ to refresh that representation directly from the filesystem.

defs.name: Flag
defs.docs: Special Notify flag on the event.

attributes.value: / Special Notify flag on the event.
/ This attribute is used to flag certain kinds of events that Notify either marks or generates in
/ particular ways.

attributes.value: / Stub `Watcher` implementation
/ Events are never delivered from this watcher.

defs.name: poll
defs.docs: Generic Watcher implementation based on polling

attributes.value: / Generic Watcher implementation based on polling
/ Checks the `watch`ed paths periodically to detect changes. This implementation only uses
/ Rust stdlib APIs and should work on all of the platforms it supports.

defs.name: PollWatcher
defs.docs: Polling based `Watcher` implementation

attributes.value: / Polling based `Watcher` implementation

defs.value: pub fn with_delay(Arc<Mutex<dyn EventFn>>, Duration) -> Result<PollWatcher>
defs.docs: Create a PollWatcher which polls every `delay` milliseconds

attributes.value: / Create a PollWatcher which polls every `delay` milliseconds

defs.name: Recursive
defs.docs: Watch all sub-directories as well, including directories created after installing the watch

attributes.value: / Watch all sub-directories as well, including directories created after installing the watch

defs.name: NonRecursive
defs.docs: Watch only the provided directory

attributes.value: / Watch only the provided directory

defs.name: RecursiveMode
defs.docs: Indicates whether only the provided directory or its sub-directories as well should be watched

attributes.value: / Indicates whether only the provided directory or its sub-directories as well should be watched

defs.name: PreciseEvents
defs.docs: Enable or disable emitting precise event classification.

attributes.value: / Enable or disable emitting precise event classification.
/ Applicable to all watchers.
/ When enabled, events are emitted with a `kind` set to as much precision about what kind of
/ event they are as the backend is capable of providing. When disabled (default), events are
/ instead emitted as `EventKind::Any`. `EventKind::Other` meta-events are left alone.

defs.name: NoticeEvents
defs.docs: Enable or disable emitting `Notice` events.

attributes.value: / Enable or disable emitting `Notice` events.
/ Applicable to debounced watchers only.
/ When enabled, the first modify or remove event for a path is emitted immediately with a
/ [`Flag::Notice`](../event/enum.Flag.html) attribute within a debouncing period, enabling
/ applications to respond more quickly.

defs.name: OngoingEvents
defs.docs: Enable or disable emitting `Ongoing` events.

attributes.value: / Enable or disable emitting `Ongoing` events.
/ Applicable to debounced watchers only.
/ When enabled, partial write events that are received after a `Modify(Data)` Notice but
/ before the end of a debouncing period (and the emission of a `Modify(Data)` event) are
/ passed through as `Modify(Data)` events with an `Ongoing` flag. These events are still
/ debounced, but at a lower (configurable) interval than the debouncing interval.
/ To enable, provide `Some(Duration)`. To disable, provide `None`.
/ # Errors
/ - `InvalidConfigValue` if the interval provided is higher than the debounce interval.

defs.name: Config
defs.docs: Runtime configuration items for watchers.

attributes.value: / Runtime configuration items for watchers.
/ See the [`Watcher::configure`](../trait.Watcher.html#tymethod.configure) method for usage.

defs.name: Result
defs.docs: Type alias to use this library's `Error` type in a Result

attributes.value: / Type alias to use this library's `Error` type in a Result

defs.name: Generic
defs.docs: Generic error

attributes.value: / Generic error
/ May be used in cases where a platform specific error is mapped to this type, or for opaque
/ internal errors.

defs.name: Io
defs.docs: I/O errors.

attributes.value: / I/O errors.

defs.name: PathNotFound
defs.docs: A path does not exist.

attributes.value: / A path does not exist.

defs.name: WatchNotFound
defs.docs: Attempted to remove a watch that does not exist.

attributes.value: / Attempted to remove a watch that does not exist.

defs.name: InvalidConfig
defs.docs: An invalid value was passed as runtime configuration.

attributes.value: / An invalid value was passed as runtime configuration.

defs.name: MaxFilesWatch
defs.docs: Can't watch (more) files, limit on the total number of inotify watches reached

attributes.value: / Can't watch (more) files, limit on the total number of inotify watches reached

defs.name: ErrorKind
defs.value:
pub enum ErrorKind {
    Generic(String),
    Io(io::Error),
    PathNotFound,
    WatchNotFound,
    InvalidConfig(Config),
    MaxFilesWatch,
}
defs.docs: Error kinds

attributes.value: / Error kinds

defs.name: Error
defs.docs: Notify error type.

attributes.value: / Notify error type.
/ Errors are emitted either at creation time of a `Watcher`, or during the event stream. They
/ range from kernel errors to filesystem errors to argument errors.
/ Errors can be general, or they can be about specific paths or subtrees. In that later case, the
/ error's `paths` field will be populated.

defs.name: kind
defs.docs: Kind of the error.

attributes.value: / Kind of the error.

defs.name: Watcher
defs.docs: Type that can deliver file activity notifications

attributes.value: / Type that can deliver file activity notifications
/ Watcher is implemented per platform using the best implementation available on that platform.
/ In addition to such event driven implementations, a polling implementation is also provided
/ that should work on any platform.

defs.name: new_immediate
defs.value: pub fn new_immediate<F>(F) -> Result<Self> where F: EventFn
defs.docs: Create a new watcher in _immediate_ mode.

attributes.value: / Create a new watcher in _immediate_ mode.
/ Events will be sent using the provided `tx` immediately after they occur.

defs.name: watch
defs.value: pub fn watch<P: AsRef<Path>>(&mut Self, P, RecursiveMode) -> Result<()>
defs.docs: Begin watching a new path.

attributes.value: / Begin watching a new path.
/ If the `path` is a directory, `recursive_mode` will be evaluated. If `recursive_mode` is
/ `RecursiveMode::Recursive` events will be delivered for all files in that tree. Otherwise
/ only the directory and its immediate children will be watched.
/ If the `path` is a file, `recursive_mode` will be ignored and events will be delivered only
/ for the file.
/ On some platforms, if the `path` is renamed or removed while being watched, behaviour may
/ be unexpected. See discussions in [#165] and [#166]. If less surprising behaviour is wanted
/ one may non-recursively watch the _parent_ directory as well and manage related events.
/ [#165]: https://github.com/notify-rs/notify/issues/165
/ [#166]: https://github.com/notify-rs/notify/issues/166

defs.name: unwatch
defs.value: pub fn unwatch<P: AsRef<Path>>(&mut Self, P) -> Result<()>
defs.docs: Stop watching a path.

attributes.value: / Stop watching a path.
/ # Errors
/ Returns an error in the case that `path` has not been watched or if removing the watch
/ fails.

defs.name: configure
defs.value: pub fn configure(&mut Self, Config) -> Result<bool>
defs.docs: Configure the watcher at runtime.

attributes.value: / Configure the watcher at runtime.
/ See the [`Config`](config/enum.Config.html) enum for all configuration options.
/ # Returns
/ - `Ok(true)` on success.
/ - `Ok(false)` if the watcher does not support or implement the option.
/ - `Err(notify::Error)` on failure.
